case_title: Kelington Engineering (S) Pte LtdvGan Cheng Chuan

sections.Introduction: 1â€ƒWhat a difference a date makes. 2â€ƒThis case involves an employment agreement between the plaintiff company, Kelington Engineering (S) Pte Ltd (â€œKelingtonâ€), and the defendant, Mr Gan Cheng Chuan (â€œMr Ganâ€). It was common ground between the parties that: (a)â€ƒsometime between October and early December 2020, Mr Gan contractually agreed to be employed by Kelington, and the parties signed a letter of appointment (the â€œLOAâ€);1Foot Note 1Ã—Plaintiffâ€™s Closing Submissions (â€œPCSâ€), paras 26-27; Defendantâ€™s Closing Submissions (â€œDCSâ€), paras 5, 10 and 14; Notes of Evidence (â€œNEâ€), 26 January 2022, page 88, lines 11â€“16. (b)â€ƒon 19 December 2020 Mr Gan repudiated that contract;2Foot Note 2Ã—PCS, para 35; DCS, Mr Gan Cheng Chuanâ€™s Affidavit of Evidence-in-Chief dated 24 November 2021 (â€œMr Ganâ€™s AEICâ€), para 17 (Bundle of Affidavits of Evidence-in-Chief (â€œBAEICâ€), pages 333â€“334).and (c)â€ƒKelington accepted that repudiation on 22 December 2020.3Foot Note 3Ã—PCS, para 35; Mr Ganâ€™s AEIC, para 18 (BAEIC, page 334). 3â€ƒMr Gan accepted that he was liable to compensate Kelington for his breach of contract, but how much was he liable for? 4â€ƒKelingtonâ€™s position is: (a)â€ƒthe agreed commencement date of Mr Ganâ€™s three-year term of employment was1 December 2020;4Foot Note 4Ã—PCS, paras 40â€“50. (b)â€ƒMr Ganâ€™s term of employment had already commenced when he purportedly quit on 19Â December 2020; (c)â€ƒon the terms of clause 1.5 of the LOA,5Foot Note 5Ã—Agreed Bundle of Documents Volume I ("AB1â€), page 77, clauses 1.3 and 1.5.Mr Gan was liable to compensate Kelington the amount equivalent to his salary for the balance of the three-year term (after 22 December 2020 when Kelington accepted MrÂ Ganâ€™s repudiation); and (d)â€ƒKelington was therefore entitled to RM1,453,565.22 after offsetting salary for the period of 1â€“22 December 2020 during which it considered Mr Gan to be an employee.6Foot Note 6Ã—Statement of Claim (â€œSOCâ€), paras 8â€“10 (Set Down Bundle (â€œSDBâ€), pages 5â€“6). 5â€ƒMr Ganâ€™s position is: (a)â€ƒon 19 December 2020, when he had changed his mind about joining Kelington and informed Kelingtonâ€™s representative, Mr Lim Seng Chuan (â€œMr Limâ€) of the same, he had not commenced his term of employment yet;7Foot Note 7Ã—Defence (Amendment No. 1), para 3 (SDB, page 21); Mr Ganâ€™s AEIC, paras 17â€“19 (BAEIC, pages 333â€“334). (b)â€ƒthe agreement/understanding between him and Kelington, was that the commencement date of Mr Ganâ€™s employment term was1January 2021(as he had to serve notice with his existing employer until the end of December 2020);8Foot Note 8Ã—DCS, paras 5â€“7. (c)â€ƒclause 9.4 of the LOA (which pertained to termination before commencement of employment) provides that the party initiating termination â€œshall be bound to pay 1 (one) monthâ€™s basic salary in lieu as compensationâ€;9Foot Note 9Ã—AB1 81, clause 9.4.and (d)â€ƒas it was clause 9.4 that applied, Mr Gan was only liable to compensate Kelington one monthâ€™s basic salary, amounting to RM24,000 â€“ much less than what Kelington was claiming from him.10Foot Note 10Ã—Defence (Amendment No. 1), para 7 (SDB, pages 24â€“25); DCS, para 17. 6â€ƒAt the hearing of Kelingtonâ€™s summary judgment application, a consent judgment was entered for the sum of RM24,000,11Foot Note 11Ã—HC/ORC 3042/2021 made on 25 May 2021, filed on 2 June 2021.which Mr Gan paid shortly thereafter.12Foot Note 12Ã—DCS, para 23.Mr Gan was granted unconditional leave to defend the rest of Kelingtonâ€™s claims, which proceeded to trial.
sections.Issues: 7â€ƒThemain issueis thus: what was the agreement/understanding between the parties as to the commencement date of Mr Ganâ€™s employment with Kelington? Was the commencement date 1 December 2020 (according to Kelington), or 1 January 2021 (according to Mr Gan)? More specifically, had Mr Gan unconditionally agreed to commence employment with Kelington on 1Â December 2020, regardless of whether he might still be serving notice with his existing employer? 8â€ƒIn the event that I find that the commencement date was 1 December 2020, there are twosubsidiary issues: (a)â€ƒIs clause 1.5 of the LOA (which requires Mr Gan to compensate Kelington the amount equivalent to his salary for the balance of his three-year term of employment) an unenforceable penalty clause? (b)â€ƒDoes the consent judgment in the sum of RM24,000 limit Kelington to recovering only that sum (which Mr Gan has already paid)?
sections.Background facts: 9â€ƒKelington and Kelington Engineering (Shanghai) Co Ltd (â€œKESHâ€) are both wholly owned subsidiaries of Kelington Group Berhad, a company listed on the stock exchange of Malaysia. In or around August 2020, Kelington had begun searching for a replacement Country Manager for KESH and, for this purpose, communicated with Mr Gan.13Foot Note 13Ã—Mr Lim Seng Chuanâ€™s Affidavit of Evidence-in-Chief dated 12 November 2021 (â€œMr Limâ€™s AEICâ€), paras 7, 8, 13 and 14.In or around October 2020, Mr Gan agreed to be employed by Kelington as the Country Manager (China) for KESH. 10â€ƒAt the end of September 2020, Mr Gan communicated to Mr Lim that he would be resigning from his existing employment.14Foot Note 14Ã—AB1, pages 95â€“96;He was, however, contractually obliged to serve three monthsâ€™ notice.15Foot Note 15Ã—Mr Ganâ€™s AEIC, para 5; NE, 26 January 2022, page 70, lines 24â€“32.This meant that unless his employer agreed to an early release, he could only commence employment with Kelington Singapore in January 2021, or he would breach his existing employment contract. Indeed, for him to have two employers at the same time would also be a breach of his contract with Kelington.16Foot Note 16Ã—AB1, page 77, clauses 11.1 and 11.2. 11â€ƒMr Ganâ€™s LOA from Kelington,17Foot Note 17Ã—AB1, page 77.however, stated that his appointment as Country Manager (China) for KESH â€œshall commence on 1stÂ December 2020â€. Mr Gan signed and returned a copy of the LOA in October 2020.
sections.Partiesâ€™ contentions: 12â€ƒKelingtonâ€™s case is that by signing the LOA, Mr Gan had unconditionally agreed to all its terms, including the commencement date of 1Â December 2020.18Foot Note 18Ã—PCS, paras 40â€“45; Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, paras 41â€“43.If he was still serving notice with his existing employer as at that date, that was Mr Ganâ€™s problem: he would be in breach of his contractual obligations owed to Kelington if he did not commence employment with Kelington on 1 December 2020 as he had contracted to. 13â€ƒMr Gan, on the other hand, says that he had made it clear to Kelington, both before and after he signed the LOA, that Kelingtonâ€™s suggested commencement date of 1 December 2020 was only â€œtentativeâ€ â€“ he could only commence employment with Kelington after serving out his notice with his existing employer, unless he were given an early release.19Foot Note 19Ã—Mr Ganâ€™s AEIC, paras 5, 8, 11, 13 and 14 (BAEIC at pages 330â€“333); NE, 26 January 2022, page 70, lines 23â€“32 and page 62, lines 12â€“31.In that regard, he had mentioned the date of 1 January 2021 (or more generally January 2021) to Kelington on several occasions, and he believed Kelington was agreeable to that.
sections.The parol evidence rule: 14â€ƒKelington relies on the parol evidence rule as enacted in ss 93 and 94 of the Evidence Act 1893 (2020 Rev Ed) (formerly Cap 97, 1997 Rev Ed) (the â€œEvidence Actâ€). It contends that the terms of Mr Ganâ€™s contract of employment were reduced to the form of a document (the LOA), and accordingly no extrinsic evidence can be admitted to contradict, vary, add to, or subtract from the terms in the LOA. Specifically, Kelington contends that since the commencement date stated in the LOA (at clause 1.3) is 1 December 2020, that cannot be contradicted (or even qualified) by any evidence outside of the LOA.20Foot Note 20Ã—PCS, paras 39â€“45. 15â€ƒHowever, the parol evidence rule only applies when it is proved that the document was intended by the parties to contain all the terms of the contract. The court must therefore first determine whether in fact the LOA was intended to contain all the terms of the partiesâ€™ agreement. In doing so, the court may look at extrinsic evidence and apply the normal objective test, subject to a rebuttable presumption that a contract which is complete on its face was intended to contain all the terms of the partiesâ€™ agreement:Zurich Insurance (Singapore) Pte Ltd v B-Gold Interior Design & Construction Pte Ltd[2008]Â 3Â SLR(R) 1029 at [40] and [110];The Law of Contract in Singapore(Andrew Phang Boon Leong gen ed) (Academy Publishing, 2012) (â€œThe Law of Contract inSingaporeâ€) at paras 06.027â€“06.028. Having done so, the court may well conclude that the LOA was not intended by the parties to contain all the terms of their contract â€“ the contract might instead be partly written and partly oral. If so, the court can consider extrinsic evidence to establish what the terms of the contract are, even, as a logical extension, where the oral evidence contradicts the written document:The Law of Contract in Singaporeat paraÂ 06.040. 16â€ƒThere are thus two questions to be dealt with: the anterior question of whether the LOA was intended by Kelington and Mr Gan to contain all the terms of their agreement; and, if it was not so intended, the subsequent question of what the terms of the agreement between the parties were (having regard to extrinsic evidence). However, as the facts pertaining to both questions overlap substantially, I will deal with them in the round.
sections.The nature of the LOA: 17â€ƒThe LOA appeared to be complete on its face. In particular, clause 1.3 stated the commencement date of Mr Ganâ€™s employment with Kelington as 1Â December 2020.21Foot Note 21Ã—AB1, page 77, clause 1.3.This gave rise to a rebuttable presumption that the LOA was intended to contain all the terms of the partiesâ€™ agreement, including the commencement date of 1 December 2020. 18â€ƒHowever, it remains open to Mr Gan to rebut that presumption by showing that the partiesâ€™ agreement/understanding was that the commencement date would be 1 January 2021, not 1 December 2020. It is also open to Mr Gan to show that even if the commencement date were 1 December 2020, it was nevertheless tentative, in that it was subject to him being released early from his existing employment by that date.
sections.The negotiations between the parties: 19â€ƒMr Ganâ€™s discussions were principally with Kelingtonâ€™s representative, Mr Lim. Mr Gan provided his resume to Mr Lim on 11 August 2020,22Foot Note 22Ã—AB1, page 21.and MrÂ Lim conducted an interview with him on 13 August 2020.23Foot Note 23Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, para 14 (BAEIC, page 10); Mr Ganâ€™s AEIC, para 5 (BAIEC, page 330).Mr Ganâ€™s evidence is that during the interview, he told Mr Lim that he would need to serve three monthsâ€™ notice with his existing employer. 20â€ƒFollowing the interview, Mr Lim told Mr Gan that Kelington was keen for him to come on board as KESHâ€™s Country Manager (China),24Foot Note 24Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, para 16 (BAEIC, page 11).and on 10Â September 2020 Mr Gan indicated that he was willing to be appointed to that position by informing Mr Lee via a WhatsApp message that he was â€œon boardâ€.25Foot Note 25Ã—AB1, page 92. 21â€ƒOn 14 September 2020, Mr Lim sent Mr Gan a WhatsApp message asking, â€œâ€¦ Commencement date 1 Dec 2020 ok for you?â€ Mr Gan replied on the same day, â€œTentativeâ€.26Foot Note 26Ã—AB1, page 92.Mr Ganâ€™s evidence is that he had indicated that the commencement date was â€œtentativeâ€ because he had yet to tender his resignation from his existing employment;27Foot Note 27Ã—Mr Ganâ€™s AEIC, para 5 (BAEIC, page 330); NE, 26 January 2022, page 70, lines 23â€“32 and page 76, lines 1â€“9.even if he had done so right away, it was already mid-September 2020, and his three-month notice period would go past 1 December 2020. 22â€ƒThe parties then negotiated other terms of Mr Ganâ€™s prospective employment with Kelington. On 15 September 2020, Mr Lim forwarded a draft LOA to Mr Gan.28Foot Note 28Ã—AB1, page 31.Clause 1.3 of the draft stated the commencement date of Mr Ganâ€™s employment with Kelington as 1 December 2020,29Foot Note 29Ã—AB1, page 32A, clause 1.3.although there had been no further discussion on the commencement date after Mr Gan had said it was â€œtentativeâ€. 23â€ƒClause 1.5 of the draft LOA provided that either party could terminate MrÂ Ganâ€™s employment by giving six monthsâ€™ written notice, or by paying six monthsâ€™ basic salary in lieu of notice.30Foot Note 30Ã—AB1, page 32A, clause 1.5. 24â€ƒMr Gan responded on 21 September 2020, highlighting certain clauses in the draft LOA that he was not comfortable with.31Foot Note 31Ã—AB1, pages 33â€“43. 25â€ƒOn 23 September 2020, Mr Lim sent Mr Gan a revised draft of the LOA.32Foot Note 32Ã—AB1, pages 44 and 55â€“63.Mr Gan asked to negotiate clause 1.5 further: he wanted a guaranteed three-year term, to be compensated with the amount equivalent to his salary for the balance of the three-year term if Kelington should terminate his employment before the three years were up. MrÂ Lim proposed that this apply mutually: if MrÂ Gan should choose to leave Kelington before three years were up, he would have to pay Kelington the amount equivalent to his salary for the balance of the three years. MrÂ Gan agreed to this, and so clauseÂ 1.5 was drafted as it now appears.33Foot Note 33Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, paras 29â€“31 (BAEIC, pages 16â€“17); NE, 26 January 2022, page 83 line 14â€“page 85 line 3. 26â€ƒOn 29 September 2020, Mr Gan sent Mr Lim a WhatsApp message to say, â€œSpeaking to my boss today. Will sign off [the LOA]â€.34Foot Note 34Ã—AB1, pages 95â€“96.MrÂ Gan then proceeded to tender his resignation. With his three-month notice period, he thus could not commence employment with Kelington on 1Â December 2020 as stated in the draft LOA, unless his existing employer agreed to waive his notice and release him early. 27â€ƒOn 1 October 2020 Mr Gan sent Mr Lim a WhatsApp message to say that he would send the LOA back that day. Shortly after, though, he sent further messages to say, â€œThe boss have not accepted my resignationâ€ and, â€œI will continue to speak with him.â€35Foot Note 35Ã—AB1, page 96.Thus, at or around the end of September 2020, Mr Gan had told his boss he was resigning, but his boss had not agreed to an early release. 28â€ƒAlthough Mr Gan had not highlighted clause 1.3 of the draft LOA as one of the clauses that he was not comfortable with whilst he was negotiating the terms of the LOA with Mr Lim (see [22]â€“[25] above), he had earlier told MrÂ Lim that Mr Limâ€™s suggested commencement date of 1 December 2020 was â€œtentativeâ€. Nevertheless, Mr Lim inserted that date in the draft LOA. I accept that Mr Lim knew that Mr Gan had to serve notice with his existing employer, and as such, could only commence employment with Kelington on 1 December 2020ifhis existing employer agreed to an early release. Otherwise, he could only commence employment with Kelington after he had finished serving notice. As his notice period ran till the end of December 2020, that meant that he could only start employment with Kelington on 1 January 2021.
sections.The execution of the LOA: 29â€ƒAt 8.30am on 2 October 2020, Mr Gan sent Mr Lim a signed copy of the execution page of the LOA (a photo sent by WhatsApp).36Foot Note 36Ã—AB1, pages 86 and 96.Mr Gan thereby stated: â€œI â€¦ hereby acknowledge and confirm that I understand and accept the appointment offered to me subject to the above mentioned terms and conditions of contract. In addition, I consent to the payment of my monthly salary and other payments due to me by direct credit through Companyâ€™s appointed Bank.â€ 30â€ƒMr Gan signed in the space provided for his signature, but he did not date the execution page in the space provided for that. 31â€ƒIn response, Mr Lim asked, â€œThe date?â€ (Mr Limâ€™s message of 2Â October 2020, 9.32am).37Foot Note 37Ã—AB1, pages 86 and 96.I accept MrÂ Limâ€™s evidence that his query was a reference to the missing date in the space for it on the execution page.38Foot Note 38Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, para 41 (BAEIC, page 21); NE, 25 January 2021, page 37, line 10â€“page 38, line 21. 32â€ƒBut that is not how Mr Gan understood Mr Limâ€™s query â€“ Mr Gan responded right away: â€œHave to be 1st Janâ€ (at 9.32am) and â€œBut you may send me works to analyseâ€ (at 9.33am). Mr Lim did not respond to that, and their next WhatsApp correspondence was on 9 October 2020.39Foot Note 39Ã—AB1, page 86. 33â€ƒMr Lim says he thought Mr Gan was saying that his signature had to be dated â€œ1st Janâ€,40Foot Note 40Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, para 41 (BAEIC, page 21).which Mr Lim thought did not make sense. However, Mr Lim claims that if there had been â€œany errors to the signature dateâ€, he preferred to only correct Mr Gan when he received the executed copy (which he received on 9 October 2020). On the stand, he maintained that he had wondered why MrÂ Gan would want his signature to be dated â€œ1st Janâ€, but he did not clarify this with Mr Gan.41Foot Note 41Ã—NE, 25 January 2022, page 77, line 32â€“page 78, line 14; page 79, lines 17â€“23. 34â€ƒMr Limâ€™s explanation is artificial, and I do not accept it â€“ if Mr Lim thought it would be an â€œerrorâ€ for Mr Gan to date the execution page 1 January 2021 (which is what he says he thought Mr Gan meant to do),42Foot Note 42Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, para 41.he would have said so rather than to wait a week to correct the error, if Mr Gan did proceed to date the execution page â€œ1st Janâ€. 35â€ƒLikewise, if the date of â€œ1st Janâ€ did not make sense to Mr Lim, he would have asked Mr Gan to clarify the matter. This is especially since the LOA, which Kelington had dated 15 September 2020, also provided that MrÂ Gan was to â€œknowledge [sic] [his] understanding and acceptanceâ€ of the LOA by signing and returning a copy â€œimmediately from the date hereof, failing which [Kelington] shall treat the offer as lapsedâ€ [emphasis added].43Foot Note 43Ã—AB1, pages 77 and 85.It would not be consistent with that for Mr Gan to purport to only accept the LOA on 1 January 2021. 36â€ƒI find that an objective, reasonable person in Mr Limâ€™s position would have known that â€œ1st Janâ€, as mentioned by Mr Gan in his WhatsApp message on 2Â October 2020, was a reference to the commencement date of his employment with Kelington: (a)â€ƒFirst, Mr Gan did not simply say â€œ1st Janâ€; he said: â€œHave to be1st Janâ€ [emphasis added]. There is no reason why Mr Ganhad todate the execution page â€œ1st Janâ€, and indeed, that did not make sense to Mr Lim. Rather, the date in questionhad to be1 January 2021 because of MrÂ Ganâ€™s notice period,ie, it was a reference to his commencement date. (b)â€ƒ Second, Mr Gan did not merely say â€œHave to be 1st Janâ€; he went on to say, â€œBut you may send me works to analyseâ€. That only makes sense if â€œ1st Janâ€ were a reference to his commencement date â€“ Mr Gan was saying that although he could only commence employment with Kelington on 1 January 2021, Kelington could nevertheless â€œsend [him] works to analyseâ€ prior to that date,ie, he could take preparatory steps in advance of his prospective employment with Kelington. If â€œ1stÂ Janâ€ were a reference to the date to be filled in on the execution page, MrÂ Ganâ€™s subsequent statement, â€œBut you may send me works to analyseâ€, would not make sense. (c)â€ƒThird, Mr Gan had to serve notice with his existing employer, and he had just told Mr Lim that his existing employer had not accepted his resignation. It follows that Mr Gan had not obtained an early release, and would have to serve out his notice. That takes one back to Mr Ganâ€™s remark to Mr Lim on 14 September 2020 that the commencement date of 1 December 2020 initially proposed by Mr Lim was merely â€œtentativeâ€ (see [21] above). In that context, when Mr Gan said, â€œHave to be 1st Janâ€, that was a reference to the commencement date. 37â€ƒThe above conclusion is reinforced by Mr Limâ€™s response (or lack thereof) when Mr Gan sent over a complete copy of the LOA on 9 October 2020, with the date1October 2020inserted on the execution page.44Foot Note 44Ã—AB1, pages 87, 96 and 77â€“85.Mr Lim did not ask Mr Gan why he had done so, even though Mr Lim claims to have understood Mr Ganâ€™s message a week earlier (â€œHave to be 1st Janâ€) to mean that Mr Gan wanted to date the execution page1 January 2021. The evidence suggests that Mr Lim never thought Mr Gan was referring to the date to be inserted on the execution page; rather, Mr Lim knew that â€œ1st Janâ€ was Mr Ganâ€™s intended commencement date of his employment with Kelington. 38â€ƒOne other notable piece of evidence is a message which KESHâ€™s then Country Manager (China), Mr Wan Siew Chuan (â€œMr Wanâ€), received from MrÂ Steven Ong (â€œMr Ongâ€) (Mr Wanâ€™s supervisor and the Chief Operating Officer of Kelington Group Berhad)45Foot Note 45Ã—NE, 27 January 2022, page 34, lines 16â€“18; AB1, pages 513â€“516.on 6 October 2020:46Foot Note 46Ã—APB2, NE 27 January 2022, page 38 line 25â€“page 39 line 10. Gan CC [Cheng Chuan] has finally confirmed joining yesterday buthe can only come to SH [Shanghai] on 1Jan 2021. Now they are talking to himto ask him to quit earlier if possible. However,letâ€™s assume that he cannot make it, so your handover target is still KH [Kevin Hu] â€¦ [emphasis added in bold italics] 39â€ƒMr Ongâ€™s message evinces his understanding that Mr Gan could only commence his employment with Kelington on 1 January 2021 because of his existing employment, and that attempts were being made to ask him to â€œquit earlierâ€ (ie, to obtain an early release from his existing employment). However, absent any confirmation that Mr Gan could obtain an early release, Kelington Group Berhad was operating under the assumption that he â€œcannot make itâ€ (ie, that he would not be able to commence his employment with Kelington earlier than 1 January 2021). On the evidence, as of 6 October 2020, Mr Lim was the only person with whom MrÂ Gan had discussed his commencement date. The inference to be drawn is therefore that MrÂ Lim understood Mr Ganâ€™s message, â€œHave to be 1st Janâ€, as a reference to his commencement date (and not the date to be inserted on the execution page), and had communicated the same to MrÂ Ong. 40â€ƒKelington seeks to draw a distinction between when Mr Gan could physically travel to Shanghai (1 January 2021), and when he could commence employment (1Â December 2020). There is, however, nothing in the evidence that indicates that if MrÂ Gan could commence employment on 1 December 2020, he would nevertheless be unable to travel to Shanghai until 1 January 2020. In particular, MrÂ Lim did not say that Mr Ganâ€™s reference to â€œ1stÂ Janâ€ in his message of 2 October 2021, meant that that was the earliest date Mr Gan could travel to Shanghai â€“ MrÂ Lim said he thought that was just about dating the execution page of the LOA.47Foot Note 47Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, para 41 (BAEIC, page 21). 41â€ƒMr Wan says he understood that Mr Gan would only be joining Kelington in January 2021,48Foot Note 48Ã—Mr Wan Siew Chuanâ€™s Affidavit of Evidence-in-Chief dated 26 November 2021 (â€œMr Wanâ€™s AEICâ€), para 6 (BAEIC, page 524).and not that Mr Gan would be joining Kelington earlier (on 1 December 2020) but could only travel to Shanghai on 1 January 2021.49Foot Note 49Ã—NE, 27 January 2022, page 40 lines 8â€“13, page 55 lines 18â€“20.Kelingtonâ€™s suggestion that 1 January 2021 was only Mr Ganâ€™s travel date would mean that Mr Wan was never informed when his successor, MrÂ Gan, would be joining Kelington as an employee, which is an unlikely scenario.
sections.Mr Ganâ€™s communications with Kelington: 42â€ƒFrom 13 October 2020 through 8 December 2020, Mr Gan liaised with Ms Joan Au (â€œJoanâ€) from Kelingtonâ€™s human resource (â€œHRâ€) department.50Foot Note 50Ã—AB1, pages 107â€“110.She asked him for details of a bank account into which his salary could be credited, and their subsequent messages on 13 October 2020 read as follows [with times stamps added]: Mr Gan: I donâ€™t have a Chinese bank acct [11:27am] Joan: I seeâ€¦ your official join date to KESH will be from 1 Dec 2020. For salary payment, we will tt to your China bank account [11.28am] Joan: Or you preferred bank to your mâ€™sia account directly? [11.29am] Mr Gan: Pls confirm with [Mr Lim] Seng Chuan that my official start date is 1st Jan [11.29am] Joan: The LOA that I received was stated 1 Dec 2020. No prob. Will reconfirm with him. [11.31am] Mr Gan: I donâ€™t mind if you pay Dec salary in Dec for the work I donâ€™t perform â˜º [11.32am] Joan: Let me know which bank account shd we bank in the salary after you have joined Thanks. [11.32am] Joan: ğŸ˜… [11.33am] 43â€ƒMr Gan consistently maintained that his commencement date was 1Â January 2021 â€“ he even joked with Joan about the possibility of Kelington paying him salary for the month of December 2020 for the work he would not have performed. Joan pointed out that the LOA stated the commencement date as 1Â December 2020, but she said she would reconfirm that with Mr Lim. She never got back to Mr Gan on this, however, even though they continued to correspond on various other HR matters from 19 October 2020 until 12Â November 2020. There was then a break before the next (and last) message from Joan, which was on 8Â December 2020. 44â€ƒI note the following: (a)â€ƒThere was no communication from Kelingtonâ€™s HR department (or, apparently, anyone else in Kelington) to Mr Gan on 1 December 2020 â€“ when, according to Kelington, Mr Gan had become an employee. Nor was there any announcement within Kelington (or the Kelington group of companies) that Mr Gan had joined Kelington that day. (b)â€ƒAlthough Joan had asked Mr Gan to provide his bank account details for salary crediting purposes â€œafter [he had] joinedâ€ (at 11.32am), MrÂ Gan never provided his bank account details, and Joan did not follow up on this even after 1 December 2020 came and went. Kelington did not pay Mr Gan salary in December â€“ instead, Kelington purported to offset an amount representing salary for 1â€“22 December 2020, against its damages claim.51Foot Note 51Ã—SOC, para 10b (SDB, page 5). 45â€ƒMr Ganâ€™s communications with Joan are consistent with his commencement date being 1 January 2021, rather than 1 December 2020.
sections.Preparatory steps: 46â€ƒFrom 22 October 2020, Kelington provided Mr Gan with information, and involved him in discussions. I regard these in the nature of preparatory steps in advance of Mr Gan commencing employment with Kelington. I accept that by 22 October 2020, Mr Gan had committed to joining Kelington, which explains his involvement in such matters from then. But that does not point towards 1 December 2020 being his commencement date rather than 1Â January 2021. 47â€ƒMr Wan was the Country Manager (China) of KESH until the end of December 2020, and his evidence was that â€œall managerial and/or executive decisions [were] well within [his] power and authorityâ€ during that period as he was â€œstill the person in charge and/or the Country Manager [(China)] until December 2020â€.52Foot Note 52Ã—Mr Wanâ€™s AEIC, para 8 (BAEIC, pages 524â€“545).Mr Gan made no such decisions as the Country Manager (China) of KESH, because MrÂ Gan never became the Country Manager (China) of KESH, whether from 1Â December 2020, or ever. On a related note, Mr Wan said that he understood Mr Ganâ€™s participation in discussions (from October into December 2020) to be as an observer only.53Foot Note 53Ã—Mr Wanâ€™s AEIC, para 8 (BAEIC, page 524), NE 27 January 2022, page 55 lines 2â€“10. 48â€ƒA transition plan was circulated by Mr Wan on 4 November 2020.54Foot Note 54Ã—AB1 at pages 124 and 316.ItemÂ 3 on the action list is â€œAnnouncementâ€, both external to customers, suppliers, and contractors, and internal to the Kelington group of companies. The stated date for Item 3 was 1 December 2020, but in the event, no announcement was made on that date. Instead, an announcement was made on 8 December 2020 which I discuss later (at [59]â€“[60]). 49â€ƒItem 4 on the action list is â€œChange of constitution and legal repâ€, for which the stated date was 17 December 2020, and for which the following elaboration was provided: â€œLegal Rep - George Ganâ€. However, no evidence was led to show that Mr Gan was appointed as a legal representative for KESH, or any other company in the Kelington group, by that date. 50â€ƒNothing in the transition plan states that Mr Gan would become a Kelington employee on 1 December 2020. What was stated under the â€œNoteâ€ section was: â€œGeorge Gan go Shanghai at 1 Jan 2021 and be able to work from mid of Jan 2021.â€ 51â€ƒThe transition plan â€“ and what was done (or not done) pursuant to it â€“ does not support Kelingtonâ€™s contention that the commencement date of MrÂ Ganâ€™s employment was 1 December 2020.
sections.Further discussions between Mr Lim and M: 52â€ƒBetween 19 and 21 October 2020, Mr Lim and Mr Gan discussed the possibility of Mr Gan shortening his notice period with his existing employer. The messages they exchanged are as follows [with date and time stamps added]:55Foot Note 55Ã—AB1, page 97. Mr Lim: Good Morning George, is it possible for you to come earlier? [19 October 2020, 10.55am] Mr Gan: Hi Seng Chuan. My release date is end Dec as of now. Seems difficult to come earlier [19 October 2020, 11.11am] Mr Lim: Due to work requirement? If by contract, can we pay to release earlier? [19 October 2020, 11.13am] Mr Gan: Due to work requirements. [19 October 2020, 11.14am] Mr Gan: I can negotiate again [19 October 2020, 11.14am] Mr Lim: Pls do so and better to go earlier by early Dec. Kevin is buying his ticket to China now. [19 October 2020, 11.15am] Mr Gan: Will let you know [19 October 2020, 11.16am] Mr Lim: Good morning, how? Can come earlier? [21 October 2020, 9.32am] Mr Gan: Cannot le [21 October 2020, 9.34am] Mr Gan: Still Jan [21 October 2020, 9.34am] Mr Lim: It will be hard for you then. Wan could not extend for 1-2 months. [21 October 2020, 10.26am] Mr Lim: Try to clear your leave [21 October 2020, 10.26am] Mr Gan: Not many leave days left [21 October 2020, 10.34am] Mr Lim: We can pay off [21 October 2020, 10.34am] Mr Gan: Cannot [21 October 2020, 11.07am] 53â€ƒMr Lim says that in asking Mr Gan to â€œcome earlierâ€ (ie, commence his employment with Kelington earlier), Mr Lim meant earlier than 1 December 2020, so that Mr Gan could travel to China before 1 January 2021.56Foot Note 56Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, para 47 (BAEIC, page 24), NE, 25 January 2022, page 39, lines 27â€“31 and page 81, lines 1â€“18.I do not accept that â€“ it is not borne out by the messages, and it is also not what Mr Gan understood. Mr Ganâ€™s response to whether he could â€œcome earlierâ€ was that his release date was â€œend Decâ€, and it seemed difficult to come earlier than that. In response, Mr Lim did not clarify that he was asking about Mr Gan commencing his employment with Kelington even earlier than 1 December 2020, rather than earlier than January 2021 as Mr Gan was referring to (see Mr Ganâ€™s messages of 19 October 2020, 11.11am and 21 October 2020, 9.34am). Instead, Mr Lim simply said it would be better for Mr Gan â€œto go [to China] earlier by early Decâ€ (his message of 19 October 2020, 11.15am). 54â€ƒThe evidence does not bear out that Mr Gan could only go to China by early December 2020 if he commenced his employment with Kelington earlier than 1 December 2020. I find that the discussions about whether he could â€œcome earlierâ€ were about him joining Kelington earlier than 1 January 2021, which was what his commencement date would otherwise be. 55â€ƒConspicuously, Mr Lim never told Mr Gan in the course of those messages that he considered Mr Gan to have contracted unconditionally to commence employment with Kelington on 1 December 2020. If Mr Lim truly believed that Mr Gan had contractually agreed to commence employment with Kelington on 1 December 2020, it would only have been natural for him to mention this, upon seeing Mr Ganâ€™s messages that he could not â€œcome earlierâ€ than January 2021. Mr Lim says he did not wish to raise that as an issue as that might create tension with Mr Gan right from the start.57Foot Note 57Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, para 48 (BAEIC, page 24).I consider that a lame excuse. 56â€ƒMr Lim went so far as to tell Mr Gan that Kelington could pay off MrÂ Ganâ€™s notice period to secure an early release,58Foot Note 58Ã—AB1, page 97.which is inconsistent with Kelingtonâ€™s position that it was MrÂ Ganâ€™s obligation to join Kelington on 1Â December 2020 come what may.
sections.Events in December 2020: 57â€ƒKelingtonâ€™s case is that Mr Gan became an employee on 1 December 2020. But on that date, Mr Gan did not report anywhere, or to anyone, for his first day of work. It does not appear that anyone even contacted him that day. There was no announcement to his colleagues, to the Kelington group of companies, or to customers, suppliers and contractors, that Mr Gan had joined Kelington as of 1Â December 2020. 58â€ƒClause 1.1 of the LOA states that Kelington appoints Mr Gan and MrÂ Gan agrees to serve as Country Manager (China) for KESH; clause 1.3 states that the appointment shall commence on 1 December 2020.59Foot Note 59Ã—AB1, page 77.In fact, however, Mr Gan was not appointed Country Manager (China) for KESH on 1 December 2020, or ever â€“ Mr Wan continued to be Country Manager (China) till the end of December 2020 (see above at [47]). If, as Kelington contends, clause 1.3 reflected the agreement/understanding between the parties on the commencement date, then Kelington acted contrary to it by not appointing MrÂ Gan as Country Manager (China) for KESH with effect from 1 December 2020. The true position is: Mr Ganâ€™s commencement date was 1 January 2021, and that is why Kelington did not appoint him Country Manager (China) for KESH with effect from 1 December 2020. 59â€ƒ On 6 December 2021, Mr Lim sent Mr Gan a draft announcement which contained the following sentence: â€œWe are very pleased to announce the hiring of Mr. Gan Cheng Chuan (George) as Country Manager for KE Shanghai, China, effective 1st Jan 2021.â€60Foot Note 60Ã—AB1, page 98.That sentence was retained in the finalised announcement (save that the date was reflected as â€œ01st Jan 2021â€ and â€œMr.â€ was omitted), which was made as a staff announcement on 8 December 2020 by the Chief Executive Officer of Kelington Group Berhad.61Foot Note 61Ã—AB1, page 478.The announcement did not say that Mr Gan had already joined Kelington as of that date; instead, it announced â€œthe hiringâ€ of Mr Gan as Country Manager (China) for KESH â€œeffective 01st Jan 2021â€. This too is consistent with MrÂ Ganâ€™s commencement date being 1 January 2021, not 1Â December 2020. 60â€ƒMr Gan was forwarded the staff announcement on 8 December 2020 by Mr Soh Tong Hwa, a non-executive director of Kelington Group Berhad, with a â€œthumbs upâ€ emoji:ğŸ‘.62Foot Note 62Ã—AB1, page 157.That bolstered the impression on Mr Ganâ€™s part, that there was consensus on 1 January 2021 being his commencement date. 61Mr Gan had, however, begun to waver in his resolve to join Kelington. He told Mr Lim on 7 December 2020 at 9.10am that his existing employer had called and made a â€œcounter offer for [him] to stayâ€.63Foot Note 63Ã—AB1, page 99.Again, Mr Ganâ€™s language is consistent with his position: he had yet to leave his existing employer or join Kelington â€“ so it was about himstayingwith his existing employer. In response, Mr Lim did not protest that Mr Gan was already a Kelington employee as of 1Â December 2020. Instead, Mr Lim simply said â€œStay firm with usâ€ (7Â December 2020, 9.24am), and â€œAnnouncement is already made by Raymond Gan. Letâ€™s move together and make life better.â€ (7 December 2020, 9.33am). 62Mr Limâ€™s subsequent message of 10 December 2020, 5.31pm is even more telling: â€œIf not because of this opportunity to join [Kelington], and [you have] committed to join us, would he make counter offer?â€64Foot Note 64Ã—AB1, page 99.Again, Mr Lim did not say that MrÂ Gan was already a Kelington employee as of 1 December 2020. Instead, he spoke of â€œthis opportunity to join [Kelington]â€, which Mr Gan had committed to. That too is consistent with Mr Ganâ€™s position that he had yet to commence his employment with Kelington, but had merely committed to doing so. 63On 19 December 2020, Mr Gan messaged Mr Lim to say, â€œâ€¦ I have decided to stay with the existing company. Sorry for all the troubles causedâ€.65Foot Note 65Ã—AB1, page 99.Mr Limâ€™s reply was simply, â€œSad to hear that.â€ He did not contradict Mr Ganâ€™s assertion that he would bestayingwith his existing company; he did not say that Mr Gan was already a Kelington employee. 64On 22 December 2020, Kelington sent Mr Gan a letter of demand,66Foot Note 66Ã—AB1, pages 480â€“481.in which it purported to characterise Mr Ganâ€™s communication to Mr Lim on 19Â December 2020 as â€œnotice that [Mr Gan] will not be continuing with [his] employment with [Kelington]â€, which Kelington accepted. The letter further purported to end Mr Ganâ€™s employment on 22 December 2020. This was an attempt to rewrite history. 65Mr Ganâ€™s pithy response on 26 December 2020 was that it was clauseÂ 9.4 of the LOA that applied, for he had terminated the contract before the commencement of his employment.67Foot Note 67Ã—AB 482.
sections.Conclusion on the Main Issue: 66â€ƒFor the above reasons, I find that Mr Gan has rebutted the presumption that the LOA was intended to contain all the terms of the partiesâ€™ agreement. Specifically, the commencement date of Mr Ganâ€™s employment term was the subject of an agreement/understanding between Mr Lim and Mr Gan, outside the LOA. The terms of the contract were not reduced to the form of a document (the LOA). As such, the parol evidence rule does not apply to prevent Mr Gan from relying on extrinsic evidence to prove the parties' agreement/understanding as to the commencement date. 67â€ƒI find that the agreement/understanding between the parties was that the commencement date of Mr Ganâ€™s employment with Kelington was 1 January 2021, not 1 December 2020. When Mr Gan repudiated the contract on 19Â December 2020, and Kelington treated the contract as terminated on 22Â December 2020, Mr Gan was not an employee of Kelington. Accordingly, it is clause 9.4 of the LOA that applies, not clause 1.5. It follows that Mr Ganâ€™s liability to Kelington was only in the sum of RM24,000, for which consent judgment was entered, and which he has already paid to Kelington. 68â€ƒFurther, even if the parol evidence rule applied, s 94(c) of the Evidence Act provides that â€œthe existence of any separate oral agreement constituting a condition precedent to the attaching of any obligation under any such contract, grant or disposition of property, may be provedâ€. Thus, it was always open to Mr Gan to prove (as he has) that it was a condition precedent to the commencement of his employment with Kelington, that he be freed of his existing employment. 69â€ƒIf at all Mr Gan agreed to 1 December 2020 being the commencement date, that was just â€œtentativeâ€ (as he put it) â€“ it was always subject to him being freed of his existing employment by then. However, his employer had not agreed to an early release; and while he was still serving notice, Mr Gan decided to stay on with his employer and not join Kelington after all. A conditional agreement to 1 December 2020 as the commencement date does not work for Kelingtonâ€™s claim under clause 1.5. If Mr Gan did not obtain an early release by 1Â December 2020, he was not obliged to commence his employment with Kelington on that date. Thereafter, he terminated the contract prior to the commencement of his employment with Kelington, and as such, clause 1.5 does not apply.
sections.Subsidiary Issue (1): was clause 1.5 of: 70â€ƒAs stated at [67] above, I find that it is clause 9.4 of the LOA, not clauseÂ 1.5, that applies. I go on to consider whether, if clause 1.5 had applied, Kelingtonâ€™s claims would nevertheless have failed on account of clause 1.5 being an unenforceable penalty clause. 71â€ƒIn determining whether clause 1.5 of the LOA is an unenforceable penalty clause, the focus is whether it provides a genuine pre-estimate of the likely lossat the time of contracting:Denka Advantech Pte Ltd and another v Seraya EnergyPte Ltd and another and other appeals[2021] 1 SLR 631 (â€œDenkaâ€) at [152] and [185]. The court will consider whether the sum stipulated is so extravagant, having regard to the range of damages which the innocent party was likely to suffer, that it was not a genuine estimate of the damages that the innocent party could have suffered:CLAAS Medical Centre Pte Ltd v Ng Boon Ching[2010] 2 SLR 386 at [67]. ClauseÂ 1.5 of the LOA would be a penalty clause if the sum stipulated is extravagant and unconscionable in amount in comparison with the greatest loss that could conceivably be proved to have followed from MrÂ Ganâ€™s breach of the LOA:Denkaat [254].
sections.Partiesâ€™ positions, and evidence: 72â€ƒMr Gan contended that a clause requiring him to pay Kelington an amount equivalent to his salary for the balance of the three-year term was an unenforceable penalty clause,68Foot Note 68Ã—DCS, paras 34â€“41.whereas Kelington contended that this was a genuine pre-estimate of its loss from Mr Gan leaving during the three-year term.69Foot Note 69Ã—PCS, paras 72â€“79; Mr Limâ€™s, AEIC paras 32â€“35. 73â€ƒThe stipulation in question was inserted by Kelington in response to MrÂ Ganâ€™s request for three yearsâ€™ worth of salary to be guaranteed, should Kelington terminate the employment within the three-year term (other than for cause under clauses 9.2 or 9.6 of the LOA). Kelingtonâ€™s position was that MrÂ Gan should similarly be required to compensate Kelington if he were to terminate the employment during the three-year term.70Foot Note 70Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, paras 29â€“31 (BAEIC, pages 16â€“17); NE, 26 January 2022, page 83 line 20â€“page 85, line 3. 74â€ƒIf not for Mr Gan asking to be assured of three yearsâ€™ worth of salary, Kelington was content to contract on the basis that either party could terminate the employment with six monthsâ€™ notice or six monthsâ€™ basic salary in lieu of notice (clause 1.5 of the first draft LOA).71Foot Note 71Ã—AB1, page 46.Moreover, both in the first draft LOA and in the executed LOA, clause 9.4 provided that for termination before commencement of employment, the party that initiated the termination would only have to pay one monthâ€™s basic salary in lieu as compensation. 75â€ƒKelingtonâ€™s contention that up to three yearsâ€™ worth of Mr Ganâ€™s salary was a genuine pre-estimate of its loss should Mr Gan decide to leave, must be viewed against that backdrop. 76â€ƒKelingtonâ€™s case on this point is constructed on two planks:72Foot Note 72Ã—PCS, paras 72â€“73. (a)â€ƒit would not be able to replace Mr Gan for the whole of the three-year term, and so it would lose the benefit of his service (or that of someone comparable) till the end of the three-year term; and (b)â€ƒKelingtonâ€™s target of 30% increase in profits each year (from 2021 to 2024) would be achieved with Mr Gan, but would not be achieved without him. 77â€ƒMr Lim asserted that the role of Country Manager (China) was critical to the growth of KESH, and the loss of Mr Gan in the midst of the three-year term would bring major disruption to the management team and seriously affect the performance of KESH. He said it would likely result in KESH not being able to meet its financial target of 30% increase in profits each year, and could potentially cause KESH to fail to maintain its previous yearâ€™s revenue. He put forward a total estimated loss to KESH over the three-year term of Mr Ganâ€™s employment should Mr Gan leave, in the sum of RMB17.5 million. However, this was expressly stated to be on theassumptionthat â€œKESHâ€™s performance in 2021 [remained] stagnant and the same as 2020â€, and that it did not improve at all in 2022, or 2023 either.73Foot Note 73Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, paras 32â€“33 (BAEIC, pages 18â€“19). 78â€ƒMr Gan disputes Kelingtonâ€™s assertions. He says: (a)â€ƒIf he left after being with KESH for only a short while, there would not be a huge impact.74Foot Note 74Ã—NE, 27 January 2022, page 7 lines 11â€“17, page 11 lines 19â€“23. (b)â€ƒIt was not the sole responsibility of the Country Manager (China) to achieve the target of 30% increase in profits each year; it depended on the collective action of the whole company.75Foot Note 75Ã—NE, 27 January 2022, page 7 lines 3â€“8. (c)â€ƒThe target was a very ambitious one, which he could not guarantee would be achieved â€“ there was a risk of the target not being achieved, which explains why there was a performance bonus in place to incentivise employees to achieve the target.76Foot Note 76Ã—NE, 27 January 2022, page 12 lines 1â€“6. 79â€ƒMr Wanâ€™s evidence is to similar effect. He did not agree that without its Country Manager (China), KESH would not be able to achieve its target of 30% growth â€“ he said that was just â€œan assumptionâ€.77Foot Note 77Ã—NE, 27 January 2022, page 53 lines 10â€“12. 80â€ƒI find Mr Limâ€™s assertions (summarised at [77] above) to be exaggerated â€“ an attempt to justify Kelingtonâ€™s claim for just under three yearsâ€™ worth of MrÂ Ganâ€™s salary, for him having left after 22 days.
sections.Time required to replace Mr Gan: 81â€ƒI am not convinced that at the time Kelington agreed terms with Mr Gan, it thought Mr Gan was irreplaceable (by a comparable candidate) for the whole of the three-year term. If Kelington could replace Mr Gan at any time before the three years were up, that would brighten up the dismal picture it paints. The fact that Kelington itself had, in clause 1.5 of the first draft LOA,78Foot Note 78Ã—AB1, page 46.proposed a mere six-month notice period (or pay in lieu thereof) is an indicator that it did not think it would need up to three years to replace Mr Gan. Moreover, on the terms of clause 9.4 of the LOA (also proposed by Kelington),79Foot Note 79Ã—AB1, page 81.Kelington was prepared to accept just one monthâ€™s worth of Mr Ganâ€™s salary as compensation if he should terminate the contract before commencing employment. 82â€ƒThe difference is stark: if the day before his commencement date, MrÂ Gan decided he would not join Kelington after all, he would only have to pay Kelington one monthâ€™s worth of his salary (pursuant to clause 9.4 of the LOA). However, if he commenced employment and then decided to quit on his first day of work, he would have to pay Kelington some three yearsâ€™ worth of his salary â€“ an amount exceeding RM1.4m (pursuant to clause 1.5 of the LOA). In terms of impact to Kelington, there is little difference between the two scenarios, but in terms of the financial consequences to Mr Gan under clauseÂ 9.4 as compared to clause 1.5, there is a huge difference. 83â€ƒMr Lim says that from 28 December 2020 to June 2021, Kelington tried but could not find a replacement for the position of Country Manager (China) of KESH.80Foot Note 80Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, para 72 (BAEIC, pages 34â€“35).I nevertheless remain unconvinced that at the time Kelington contracted with Mr Gan, Kelington expected that it would need up to three years to replace him. 84â€ƒA sliding scale of compensation proportionate to the balance of MrÂ Ganâ€™s term of employment does not bear any relation to the time Kelington would need to replace him, unless Kelington could only find a suitable replacement three years from Mr Ganâ€™s commencement date. I do not accept that Kelington would require that much time (or that Kelington thought it would, at the time of contracting with Mr Gan). 85â€ƒAccordingly, clause 1.5 cannot be justified as a genuine pre-estimate of the likely loss flowing from Mr Ganâ€™s breach, in terms of Kelington having to replace him.
sections.Disruption to KESH: 86â€ƒIn terms of the disruption to KESH caused by Mr Ganâ€™s departure, requiring MrÂ Gan to pay a large sum if he only assumed the role of Country Manager (China) for a short period of time does not make sense. I accept MrÂ Ganâ€™s evidence that if he only joined KESH for a short while, the disruption caused to KESH by his departure would be less than if he had joined for quite a while; yet he would have to pay more despite having caused less disruption. For instance, it would generally be more disruptive if Mr Gan left after one and a half years (midway through the three-year term), than if he left after his first day of work; yet he would have to pay double in the latter scenario, as compared to the former. 87â€ƒA sliding scale of compensation proportionate to the balance of MrÂ Ganâ€™s term of employment does not bear any relation to the disruption which MrÂ Ganâ€™s departure would cause, and as a necessary consequence, does not provide a genuine pre-estimate of the likely loss (in terms of disruption to KESH) which may flow from Mr Ganâ€™s breach.
sections.Impact of KESH not having a Country Mana: 88â€ƒI prefer the evidence of Mr Gan and Mr Wan, to that of Mr Lim, as to the impact of KESH not having a Country Manager (China) on its target profits. 89â€ƒThere was no real evidence that the target of 30% increase in profits each year for 2021, 2022 and 2023 was likely to be achieved with Mr Gan as Country Manager (China) of KESH. Nor was there any evidence that it was likely not to be achieved if MrÂ Gan terminated his employment. Indeed, there was no real evidence of what Kelington thought about this. 90â€ƒMr Lim took a target, applied an assumption to it, added assertions, and arrived at a huge â€œtotal estimated lossâ€. However, Mr Limâ€™s own language lacked conviction: he used uncertain and qualified phrases like â€œwould likelyresult inâ€, â€œcould potentiallycauseâ€; â€œKESHmight notbe able to achieve its 30% growth targetâ€; and â€œAssumingKESHâ€™s performance in 2021 remains stagnantâ€ [emphasis added].81Foot Note 81Ã—Mr Limâ€™s AEIC, paras 32â€“33 (BAEIC, page 18). 91â€ƒThe fact that 30% growth each year was expressed as atargetsuggests that it was something to aspire to, rather than something which Kelington considered likely to be achieved. 92â€ƒI accept Mr Ganâ€™s description of the target as a very ambitious one, which he could not be sure of achieving even if he took on the job. I also accept that both Mr Gan and Mr Wan viewed the target as being in the nature of anassumptionrather than a certainty. 93â€ƒThe maximum amount payable by Mr Gan under clause 1.5 is some three yearsâ€™ worth of his salary (over RM1.4m), if Mr Gan were to leave on his first day of work. Kelington has not shown that Mr Ganâ€™s departure in those circumstances, or indeed at any point during the three-year term, would likely cause it loss of such magnitude. I find that the sum of over RM1.4m is extravagant or unconscionable in amount compared with the greatest possible loss that could conceivably be proved to have followed from the breach, and that attracts the application of the penalty rule (Denkaat [254]).
sections.Significance of clause 1.5 being a negot: 94â€ƒKelington says that its entitlement to compensation under clause 1.5 was part of the bargain between the parties,82Foot Note 82Ã—PCS, para 71.but the same may be said of any contractual stipulation which is attacked as a penalty clause. I do accept it is relevant that clause 1.5 was a negotiated clause, and that it was meant to apply mutually to Kelington and Mr Gan (who wanted three yearsâ€™ worth of salary to be guaranteed). However, this does not mean that clauseÂ 1.5 is immune from challenge as a penalty clause. Rather, if clause 1.5 were found to be a penalty clause insofar as it operates in favour of Kelington, the consequence may well be that Mr Gan too cannot enforce clause 1.5 to obtain three yearsâ€™ worth of salary in any event. 95â€ƒOn a related note, Kelington contends that clause 1.5 should be upheld because the parties were of equal bargaining power.83Foot Note 83Ã—PCS, paras 60â€“70.While the comparable bargaining positions of the parties is a relevant consideration, there need not be any disparity of power between the contracting parties for the penalty rule to operate (Denkaat [174]). In considering factors such as the relative bargaining power of the parties, the focus remains on whether the clause concerned is a genuine pre-estimate of the likely loss (Denkaat [153]). A negotiated clause between parties of comparable bargaining power may nevertheless be found to be a penalty clause (Denkaat [254]).
sections.Conclusion on Subsidiary Issue (1): 96â€ƒFor the above reasons, I conclude that clause 1.5 is an unreasonable penalty clause: requiring Mr Gan to compensate Kelington the amount equivalent to his salary for the balance of the three-year term did not provide a genuine pre-estimate of the likely damage that would be caused by Mr Ganâ€™s breach, whether in terms of the time it would take to replace Mr Gan, the disruption to KESH, or the impact of Mr Ganâ€™s absence on KESHâ€™s target profits. As such, even if the commencement date were 1 December 2020, and that was not subject to the condition precedent of Mr Gan being freed of his existing employment, Kelingtonâ€™s claims based on clause 1.5 would fail for clause 1.5 being an unenforceable penalty clause.
sections.Subsidiary Issue (2): does the consent j: 97â€ƒCounsel for Mr Gan argued that because Kelington agreed to a consent judgment for RM24,000 (which has since been paid), it cannot claim anything more from Mr Gan.84Foot Note 84Ã—DCS, para 23. 98â€ƒPursuant to the doctrine of merger, when a judgment has been given on a cause of action, the cause of action merges with the judgment of the court and ceases to have an independent existence:MichaelVaz Lorrain v Singapore Rifle Association[2020] 2 SLR 808 at [14]â€“[15]. 99â€ƒHere, the only cause of action Kelington pursues against Mr Gan is breach of contract. Kelingtonâ€™s case is that Mr Gan is liable to compensate it RM1,453,565.22 for breaching the LOA; Mr Ganâ€™s case is that he is only liable for RM24,000. A consent judgment was previously entered for RM24,000 in HC/ORC 3042/2021 (â€œthe Court Orderâ€) as Mr Gan had accepted liability under clause 9.4 of the LOA.85Foot Note 85Ã—HC/SUM 1350/2021, Minute Sheet, 25 May 2021, pages 6 and 8. 100â€ƒAt first blush, it would appear that Kelingtonâ€™s cause of action had merged with that judgment, and it could no longer pursue that cause of action at trial. 101â€ƒThat was, however, not the tenor of the Court Order in which the consent judgment was embodied.86Foot Note 86Ã—HC/ORC 3042/2021 made on 25 May 2021, filed on 2 June 2021.Paragraph 1 of the Court Order recorded the consent judgment in favour of Kelington for RM24,000. However, paragraph 2 of the Court Order stated that Mr Gan was granted unconditional leave to defendthe rest ofKelingtonâ€™s claims, and paragraph 3 of the Court Order stated that costs shall be in the cause, fixed at $4,000 (all in). It is implicit in paragraphs 2 and 3 that Kelington still had claims to pursue at trial. 102â€ƒKelington, though, only had one cause of action, rather than several causes of action out of which judgment had only been entered for one. If Kelingtonâ€™s sole cause of action had merged with the consent judgment for RM24,000, it could no longer continue with that cause of action to recover the balance of the RM1,453,565.22 that it had claimed. 103â€ƒAt the summary judgment hearing, it was not contended that the consent judgment would have that effect. Instead, it appears to have been common ground that Kelington could treat the RM24,000 as merely satisfying its claims in part, and continue to trial for the rest of what it was claiming. 104â€ƒCompounding the matter, one possible outcome of the trial was a finding that the commencement date of Mr Ganâ€™s employment term was 1Â December 2020 but that clause 1.5 of the LOA was an unenforceable penalty clause. In that scenario, Kelingtonâ€™s claim for RM1,453,565.22 pursuant to clause 1.5 would fail. In principle, Kelington would still be entitled to damages for breach of contract (nominal or otherwise), but those damages would not necessarily be as much as the sum of RM24,000 in the consent judgment. If the court found that Kelington was only entitled to a sum less than RM24,000, that would then contradict the consent judgment. 105â€ƒIn its statement of claim, Kelington had sought the sum of RM1,453,565.22 â€œor such other sum as this Honourable Court deems fitâ€.87Foot Note 87Ã—SOC (SDB, page 6)However, Kelington adduced no evidence to prove what loss Mr Ganâ€™s breach of contract had actually caused it; instead, Kelington simply claimed on the basis that Mr Gan was liable to pay the balance of three yearsâ€™ worth of his salary (after offsetting the salary due to Mr Gan for his employment from 1 to 22 December 2020), pursuant to clause 1.5. If that claim failed because clauseÂ 1.5 was an unenforceable penalty clause, then Kelington would only have received nominal damages, for which I would not have awarded as much as RM24,000. 106â€ƒAs such, when the consent judgment was entered, the parties could not be sure that Mr Gan would be liable to Kelington for RM24,000 in any event. It would have been better to order the sum of RM24,000 as an interim payment, rather than to enter a consent judgment â€“ in the case of an interim payment, there can be an adjustment, if necessary, at the time of final judgment. 107â€ƒIn the awkward situation which has arisen, I would interpret the consent judgment in the context of the whole Court Order,ie, the consent judgment for RM24,000 was awarded on the premise that Kelington could continue with its claims at trial for the balance of the RM1,453,565.22 which it had originally claimed, as well as for interest and costs. Kelingtonâ€™s cause of action merges with that consent judgment, but its right to continue pursuing the balance of its claim is preserved by the same order of court. I regard the consent judgment as being in the nature of an interlocutory judgment on liability, with the trial being to determine what, if anything, Kelington was still entitled to recover, besides the sum of RM24,000. 108â€ƒThe consent judgment would still have conflicted with a potential finding that Kelington was only entitled to a sum less than RM24,000, but that is not the finding I have made. In any event, it appears that Mr Gan was content to pay Kelington RM24,000 regardless of the outcome of the trial â€“ he did not indicate that he would seek any adjustment to that sum. 109â€ƒOn Subsidiary Issue (2), I thus find that the consent judgment does not preclude Kelington from seeking a higher sum at trial.
sections.Conclusion: 110â€ƒFor the above reasons, save for the consent judgment for RM24,000 which has already been satisfied by Mr Gan (and which I do not disturb), I dismiss all of Kelingtonâ€™s claims against Mr Gan. 111â€ƒUnless the parties are able to agree on costs, they are to file costs submissions, limited to 8 pages (excluding any schedule of disbursements), within 14 days.
